review.title: Finding Preference Profiles of Condorcet Dimension $k$ via SAT
review.abstract: Condorcet winning sets are a set-valued generalization of the well-known concept of a Condorcet winner. As supersets of Condorcet winning sets are always Condorcet winning sets themselves, an interesting property of preference profiles is the size of the smallest Condorcet winning set they admit. This smallest size is called the Condorcet dimension of a preference profile. Since little is known about profiles that have a certain Condorcet dimension, we show in this paper how the problem of finding a preference profile that has a given Condorcet dimension can be encoded as a satisfiability problem and solved by a SAT solver. Initial results include a minimal example of a preference profile of Condorcet dimension 3, improving previously known examples both in terms of the number of agents as well as alternatives. Due to the high complexity of such problems it remains open whether a preference profile of Condorcet dimension 4 exists.
histories: Corrected typos, updated references, and added conclusion

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The contribution of this paper is twofold: First, we offer a practical implementation to find a preference profile for a particular Condorcet dimension by encoding the problem as a Boolean satisfaction problem (SAT) [2], which is then solved by a SAT solver. This technique has proven useful for a number of other problems in the theory of social choice (see e.g. [8, 6, 4, 3]) and can be easily customized. For example, few changes need to be made to answer similar questions for dominant sets, rather than Condorcet profit rates. Second, we give an answer to an open question by Elkind et al. [5] and provide a minimal example of a Condorcet dimension 3 preference profile, which we have calculated with our implementation. This profile comprises only 6 alternatives and agents, improving the size of previous examples both in relation to agents and alternatives. sections.heading: 3.2 Optimized computation
sections.text: Note that from a given example of a preference profile R with dimC (R) ≥ k, one can generate more and more examples simply by permutating the (names of) alternatives. It could be said that all positive witnesses of the SAT CheckCondorcet dimension k problem are invariant under permutations of the alternatives. Therefore, we have implemented a standard technique in the SAT solution, the so-called symmetry breaking, here in the form of the preferences of Agent 1 over a fixed preference order, for example over lexicographic preferences. This limits the search space for the SAT solver and thus reduces the runtime of the solving process. Coding can be achieved simply by adding a subformula of the form гx < yr (n1, x, y), which specifies the preferences of the first agents in lexicographic order.

sections.heading: 4. INITIAL RESULTS
sections.text: All calculations were carried out on an Intel Core i5, 2.66 GHz (quad-core) computer with 12 GB of RAM, using plingeling [1] by the SAT solver. When called with the parameters n = m = 6, our implementation of SAT-Check-Condorcet-Dimension-k delivers the preference profile Rdim3 within about a second. Rdim3 is a smallest preference profile of the Condorcet dimension 3 and is shown in Figure 2.5 Furthermore, this preference profile shows a smallest profile of the Condorcet dimension 3. All strictly smaller profiles (i.e. with fewer agents and at most as many alternatives or with fewer alternatives and at most as many agents) have a condorcet dimension of no more than 2 via SAT-Check-Condorcet-Check-3.6An overview of further (preliminary) results can be found in Table 2.5The witnesses for all sets, e.g. A, where a Dorncet size of maximum 2 can only be achieved by means of a condorcet-Check-SAT-only 3.6c.
